questions.text: A 70-year-old man comes to the physician because of episodes of watery stools for the past 6 weeks. During this period, he has also had recurrent episodes of reddening of the face, neck, and chest that last up to 30 minutes, especially following alcohol consumption. He has hypertension. Current medications include enalapril. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years but quit 8 years ago. He drinks two glasses of wine daily. He appears pale. He is 185 cm (6 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 67 kg (147.7 lb); BMI is 20 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. Scattered expiratory wheezing is heard throughout both lung fields. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of urea nitrogen and creatinine are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although this patient has symptoms of flushing, idiopathic flushing in particular often occurs in younger patients and in women. Furthermore, idiopathic flushing is not associated with other symptoms this patient has, such as diarrhea and wheezing, making another diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Although irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) may manifest with chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea, roughly 50% of reported cases occur in individuals younger than 35 years of age. The patient's age makes a diagnosis of IBS less likely. IBS is also not associated with cutaneous flushing or wheezing.

C) INCORRECT:

Hodgkin lymphoma (HL) may cause weight loss, but it is not associated with wheezing, diarrhea, or flushing after alcohol ingestion. A normal CBC also makes HL an unlikely diagnosis. Most patients with classical HL present with asymptomatic lymphadenopathy, a mediastinal mass that may cause coughing (not wheezing), B symptoms (fever, weight loss, night sweats), or generalized pruritus.
Image Description:

X-ray chest (a: PA view; b: left lateral view) and CT chest (c: with contrast; coronal plane) of a patient with nodular sclerosing Hodgkin lymphoma

The PA radiograph shows an abnormal superior mediastinum that is dense, markedly widened, and lobulated (green overlay). On the lateral radiograph, there is opacification of the retrosternal space, which should normally be a clear area. CT confirms the presence of a large anterior locally invasive mediastinal soft tissue mass (arrows).

Li: liver; LV: left ventricle

D) INCORRECT:

Although patients with celiac disease (CD) often manifest with chronic diarrhea, the late onset of the disease, the presence of facial flushing and wheezing, and the lack of skin abnormalities make CD less likely. CD also often manifests with other malabsorption symptoms such as vitamin deficiencies and osteoporosis, as well as dermatitis herpetiformis and vitiligo.

E) INCORRECT:

Polycythemia vera (PV) manifests with symptoms of facial flushing. However, PV is usually also associated with neurological symptoms (dizziness, headache, tinnitus), hypertension, pruritus, splenomegaly, and mucosal bleeding. Furthermore, an elevated red blood cell mass on complete blood count would be expected in a patient with PV, whereas this patient's CBC values are within normal limits. Moreover, PV is not usually associated with diarrhea and wheezing, making another diagnosis more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

VIPoma can manifest with chronic watery diarrhea, along with the resultant dehydration, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria, as well as cutaneous flushing. However, VIPoma is characterized by elevated vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) levels and manifests with other findings like abdominal pain and anemia. Moreover, wheezing is very rare in cases of VIPoma.

G) CORRECT:

Carcinoid syndrome is most likely responsible for the secretory diarrhea, episodic cutaneous flushing, and wheezing that this patient is experiencing. Neuroendocrine tumors usually occur in the gastrointestinal tract and are often asymptomatic due to hepatic metabolism of any serotonin that the tumors produce. In the case of extraintestinal neuroendocrine tumors, or tumors that have metastasized to the liver, the increased serotonin that bypasses hepatic first-pass metabolism and ends up in systemic circulation causes the symptoms of carcinoid syndrome. Episodic flushing is characteristic of carcinoid syndrome and may occur spontaneously or be provoked by eating, drinking alcohol, defecation, emotional events, palpation of the liver, or anesthesia.

Other effects of serotonin-producing neuroendocrine tumors include endocardial fibrosis resulting in tricuspid valve insufficiency and/or pulmonary valve abnormality (carcinoid heart disease), as well as pellagra.
Image Description:

Left: Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) located in the gastrointestinal tract are usually asymptomatic because most of the hormones they produce are metabolized by the first-pass effect in the liver (although local tumor growth may be symptomatic). Disseminated NETs (most commonly with liver metastases) and primary extraintestinal NETs bypass or impair this process and are more likely to be symptomatic.

Right: symptoms of the carcinoid syndrome
questions.hint: This patient presents with abdominal tenderness, diarrhea, cutaneous flushing, and wheezing, all of which are suggestive of a specific neuroendocrine neoplasm.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-month history of watery diarrhea and episodic crampy abdominal pain. He has no fever, nausea, or vomiting. Over the past 6 months, he has had a 1.8-kg (4-lb) weight loss, despite experiencing no decrease in appetite. His wife has noticed that sometimes his face and neck become red after meals or when he is in distress. A year ago, he was diagnosed with asthma. He has hypertension. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler and enalapril. He drinks one beer daily. His temperature is 36.7°C (98.0°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard best at the left sternal border and fourth intercostal space. The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Achlorhydria is part of WDHA syndrome (watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria), which is seen in VIPomas. The unregulated production of vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) leads to excessive secretion of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, causing WDHA syndrome. Cutaneous flushing is seen in about 20% of patients with VIPoma. However, this etiology does not explain why the patient also presents with a tricuspid murmur and asthma, neither of which is associated with VIPomas.

B) INCORRECT:

Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma is a complication of celiac disease (CD), along with ulcerative jejunitis and adenocarcinoma of the small bowel. Although the patient has had weight loss and diarrhea, he does not have the typical steatorrhea seen in CD. He also lacks other manifestations of CD such as malabsorption symptoms (e.g., anemia) and dermatitis herpetiformis. Furthermore, CD does not explain why this patient also presents with flushing, tricuspid murmur, and asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

Megaloblastic anemia is usually due to folate or vitamin B12 deficiency and is commonly associated with malnutrition or malabsorption. Folate deficiency can also be caused specifically by folate antagonists, and vitamin B12 deficiency can also be seen in pernicious anemia or after gastrectomy, neither of which would be the case in this patient. While malabsorption can occur in carcinoid syndrome, it is usually not severe enough to cause folate or B12 deficiency. Another complication is more likely to affect this patient.

Gastric carcinoid tumors can cause pernicious anemia. However, because these tumors produce histamine but not serotonin, they lack some of the typical features of metastatic intestinal carcinoids that are present here (e.g., diarrhea, carcinoid heart disease).

D) CORRECT:

Dementia is one of the symptoms of pellagra, which also include dermatitis, diarrhea, and glossitis. Pellagra, or niacin deficiency, is a possible complication of carcinoid syndrome. There is increased metabolism of serotonin in carcinoid tumors, which depletes tryptophan precursors available for other organic compounds, including niacin.

Patients should undergo 24-hour urine testing for 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), the end product of serotonin metabolism. Imaging tests (e.g., CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis) are then used to localize and stage the tumor. The treatment of choice in patients with carcinoid syndrome is surgical resection of the tumor. In inoperable cases, somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide) can be given to relieve symptoms and prevent complications of the disease, including niacin deficiency.
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

E) INCORRECT:

Intestinal fistulas, typically involving the terminal ileum and the perianal area, are commonly seen in patients with Crohn disease (CD). These fistulas are the result of the chronic inflammation, fibrosis, and scarring of the intestinal walls. This patient has chronic diarrhea, episodic crampy abdominal pain, and associated weight loss. However, this patient does not have bloody or mucoid diarrhea, which is typically seen in inflammatory bowel disease. Furthermore, CD does not explain why the patient also presents with flushing, tricuspid murmur, and asthma.
questions.hint: Watery diarrhea, crampy abdominal pain, episodic cutaneous flushing triggered by eating or emotional events, asthma-like attacks, and a murmur indicative of tricuspid regurgitation are highly suggestive of carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman comes to the physician for right lower abdominal pain for the past 6 months. She has multiple nonbloody, watery bowel movements daily and experiences abdominal cramping. Sometimes, she feels sudden palpitations and shortness of breath, and her face becomes red. She has lost 7 kg (15 lb) over the past 3 months. She went on a 3-week hiking trip to Cambodia 6 months ago. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years. Her temperature is 37.0˚C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg. On physical examination, tiny blood vessels are noted on the face and arms. Lung auscultation shows bilateral wheezing. The abdomen is soft and nondistended. There is localized tenderness to the right lower quadrant but no rebound tenderness or guarding. Laboratory studies show:


Leukocyte count
4600/mm3 



Segmented neutrophils
61%


Eosinophils
2%


Platelet count
254,000/mm3



Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL


Serum



 AST
110 IU/L


 ALT
128 IU/L


 C-reactive protein
8 mg/dL (N = 0–10)


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic watery diarrhea is the main symptom of VIPomas (tumors that secrete vasoactive intestinal polypeptide, VIP). Dehydration, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria are also typically present in this condition. Although cutaneous flushing can occasionally occur in individuals with a VIPoma, this diagnosis would not explain this patient's telangiectasia and wheezing.

B) INCORRECT:

Chronic appendicitis typically manifests with right lower quadrant pain persisting for more than three weeks. The diagnosis is usually made by postoperative relief of symptoms and histopathological confirmation of appendicitis. Chronic appendicitis can manifest with abdominal tenderness, along with normal markers of inflammation (CRP, leukocyte count). However, it is not associated with cutaneous flushing, telangiectasia, or pulmonary symptoms, making another diagnosis more likely.

C) INCORRECT:

Ascaris lumbricoides infection can cause pulmonary symptoms, such as wheezing and shortness of breath (larvae migrate to the lungs), as well as abdominal symptoms, including abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, and features of appendicitis (right lower quadrant complaints due to obstruction of the appendix by adult worms). Furthermore, this patient is at increased risk for ascariasis, as she spent time in Cambodia, which is endemic for A. lumbricoides. However, this type of infection would typically cause eosinophilia and is normally not associated with cutaneous flushing and telangiectasia.

D) INCORRECT:

In patients with pheochromocytoma, the catecholamines released by the tumor can lead to palpitations and flushing. A suprarenal mass is sometimes palpable and may manifest with localized abdominal tenderness. However, pheochromocytomas typically cause episodic blood pressure crises, while this patient has normal orthostatic vital signs. Additionally, the liver function tests would be unaffected.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient has some typical features of ulcerative colitis, a type of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) that manifests with chronic abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. Ulcerative colitis is most common in middle-aged women, but it typically causes bloody diarrhea with mucus, elevated markers of inflammation (CRP, white blood cell count), and fever. Moreover, IBD would not explain this patient's cutaneous flushing, telangiectasia, and wheezing.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's clinical features (cutaneous flushing, watery diarrhea, abdominal pain, wheezing) suggest carcinoid syndrome, which is most commonly associated with metastatic neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) in the gastrointestinal tract. Nonmetastasized gastrointestinal NETs are often asymptomatic because the neuroendocrine substances produced by the tumors (particularly serotonin) are metabolized by the liver. Extraintestinal NETs and/or those that metastasize to the liver lead to elevated transaminases, as seen in this patient. Symptoms are caused by increased serotonin bypassing hepatic first-pass metabolism and entering systemic circulation.
Image Description:

Left: Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) located in the gastrointestinal tract are usually asymptomatic because most of the hormones they produce are metabolized by the first-pass effect in the liver (although local tumor growth may be symptomatic). Disseminated NETs (most commonly with liver metastases) and primary extraintestinal NETs bypass or impair this process and are more likely to be symptomatic.

Right: symptoms of the carcinoid syndrome

G) INCORRECT:

Bronchogenic carcinoma (especially small cell lung carcinoma) is associated with various paraneoplastic syndromes. Most of the clinical findings in this patient could be explained by paraneoplastic syndromes due to a release of neuroendocrine substances. This patient has some features of bronchogenic carcinoma, including pulmonary symptoms (wheezing, shortness of breath), and weight loss as well as a risk factor in her history of tobacco use. Meanwhile, elevated transaminases could be explained by metastatic liver disease secondary to bronchogenic carcinoma. However, the patient's age and her localized abdominal pain with tenderness in the right lower quadrant make another diagnosis more likely.
questions.hint: If left untreated, this patient's condition may lead to tricuspid insufficiency and/or pulmonary stenosis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of crampy abdominal pain, recurrent watery diarrhea, and a 2.5-kg (5.5-lb) weight loss. Her husband has noticed that after meals, her face and neck sometimes become red, and she develops shortness of breath and starts wheezing. Examination shows a grade 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left lower sternal border. The abdomen is soft, and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Without treatment, this patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased gastric pH levels are not associated with carcinoid syndrome but are seen in achlorhydria, which is a key feature of WDHA syndrome (watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria) seen in VIPomas. The unregulated production of VIP leads to excessive secretion of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen. Cutaneous flushing is seen in about 20% of patients with VIPoma. However, abdominal pain is usually mild or absent. Furthermore, this etiology does not explain why the patient also presents with a tricuspid murmur and asthma, neither of which are typical findings of VIPomas.

B) INCORRECT:

Laryngeal edema is not associated with carcinoid syndrome but commonly occurs in hereditary angioedema, a bradykinin-mediated reaction that can also cause colicky abdominal pain and diarrhea. However, episodic cutaneous flushing and a tricuspid regurgitation murmur would not be expected. Although mast cell-mediated angioedema can cause flushing, it does not present with abdominal pain or diarrhea.

C) CORRECT:

Dermatitis is a characteristic feature of pellagra, or niacin deficiency; other key findings include dementia and diarrhea (i.e., the “three Ds”). Dermatitis in patients with pellagra is characterized by a symmetrical, pigmented, scaly thickening of the skin in sun-exposed areas, such as the limbs and around the neck (casal necklace). The increased metabolism of serotonin in neuroendocrine neoplasms depletes the amount of tryptophan precursors available for other organic compounds, including niacin. A lack of niacin leads to decreased production of the coenzymes NAD+ and NADP+, which are essential in redox reactions throughout cellular metabolism. Diagnosis is confirmed via 24-hour urine testing for 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), the end product of serotonin metabolism.

In developed countries, pellagra is most commonly seen in patients with alcohol use disorder or as a complication of malabsorption. It can also occur in Hartnup disease (due to renal and intestinal loss of tryptophan) or after prolonged use of isoniazid (due to decreased levels of vitamin B6, which is essential for the production of niacin).
Image Description:

Pellagra can be deadly if left untreated (due to the formerly high mortality rate, “death” is sometimes still listed as the fourth “D” of pellagra). Populations with a diet low in niacin-rich foods (e.g., corn-based diets without proper preparation) are at higher risk.

D) INCORRECT:

Megaloblastic anemia is not caused by carcinoid syndrome but is usually due to folate deficiency or vitamin B12 deficiency and is commonly associated with malnutrition or malabsorption. Specific causes for folate deficiency include the use of folate antagonists, whereas vitamin B12 deficiency is seen in pernicious anemia or after gastrectomy. Although malabsorption can occur in carcinoid syndrome, it is usually not severe enough to cause folate or vitamin B12 deficiency. Another complication is more likely to affect this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma is not associated with carcinoid syndrome but is a complication of celiac disease. Although this patient has had weight loss and diarrhea, she lacks other typical manifestations of celiac disease, such as steatorrhea, malabsorption symptoms (e.g., anemia), and dermatitis herpetiformis. Furthermore, celiac disease does not explain this patient's tricuspid murmur, asthma, and flushing.
questions.hint: Watery diarrhea, crampy abdominal pain, episodic cutaneous flushing triggered by eating or emotional events, asthma-like attacks, and a murmur indicative of tricuspid regurgitation are highly suggestive of carcinoid syndrome. Neuroendocrine neoplasms are highly metabolically active and can secrete excess amounts of serotonin.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and a weight loss of 4 kg (8.8 lb) over the last 4 months. She has recently avoided drinking alcohol and eating spicy food because it worsens her diarrhea and causes episodes of heart palpitations and reddening of the face and neck. She takes lisinopril for hypertension. Her temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 149/90 mm Hg. The abdomen is soft and there is mild tenderness to palpation with no guarding or rebound. Laboratory studies show an increased urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration. Further evaluation of this patient will most likely show which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Achlorhydria is seen in patients with VIPoma, a condition that manifests with watery diarrhea, tea-colored stools, and hypokalemia. Although approximately 20% of patients experience flushing symptoms, they typically do not have abdominal pain. Moreover, VIPoma is associated with increased serum concentrations of vasoactive intestinal peptide, not increased urine 5-HIAA concentration.

B) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma can manifest as an adrenal medullary mass and cause episodic hypertension, palpitations, tachycardia, and sweating. However, this malignancy does not typically cause abdominal cramps or diarrhea. Moreover, laboratory changes associated with pheochromocytoma include increased urine concentrations of catecholamines and metanephrines, not increased urine 5-HIAA.

C) INCORRECT:

Purple-red colored urine is observed in patients with acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), which also manifests with abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and, during acute attacks, hypertension and tachycardia. In addition, alcohol can precipitate attacks of AIP. However, affected patients typically experience neurological symptoms (e.g., sensory and motor neuropathy, neuropsychiatric symptoms). Moreover, laboratory changes associated with AIP include increased serum and urine concentrations of porphobilinogen, delta-aminolevulinic acid, and porphyrins, not increased urine 5-HIAA concentration.

D) INCORRECT:

Multiple peptic ulcers can result from excessive gastrin secretion due to a gastrinoma, which also manifests with severe abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. However, this woman has episodic palpitations and facial flushing triggered by food and alcohol, which are not features of a gastrinoma. Moreover, gastrinoma is associated with increased serum concentrations of gastrin and chromogranin A, not increased urine 5-HIAA concentration.

E) CORRECT:

Pulmonic valve stenosis is a manifestation of carcinoid heart disease, a condition that eventually affects > 50% of patients with carcinoid syndrome. Carcinoid heart disease typically develops as a result of chronic exposure of the heart to serotonin from liver metastases. Serotonin enters the inferior vena cava and reaches the right side of the heart, where it induces valvular and myocardial fibrosis. This can lead to pulmonary valve stenosis, tricuspid insufficiency, and right-sided heart failure.
Image Description:

Left: Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) located in the gastrointestinal tract are usually asymptomatic because most of the hormones they produce are metabolized by the first-pass effect in the liver (although local tumor growth may be symptomatic). Disseminated NETs (most commonly with liver metastases) and primary extraintestinal NETs bypass or impair this process and are more likely to be symptomatic.

Right: symptoms of the carcinoid syndrome
questions.hint: This woman has carcinoid syndrome, which manifests with abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and episodic cutaneous flushing and palpitations triggered by food ingestion. The diagnosis is confirmed by laboratory testing that shows an increased urine concentration of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is a product of serotonin metabolism.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of nonbloody diarrhea and recurrent episodes of flushing and wheezing. She does not take any medications. Physical examination shows a hyperpigmented rash around the base of her neck. Cardiac examination shows a grade 3/6, holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Echocardiography shows right-sided endocardial and valvular fibrosis with moderate tricuspid regurgitation; there are no septal defects or left-sided valvular defects. Urinalysis shows increased 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Tumor in the pancreas without metastasis
Tumor in the terminal ileum with hepatic metastasis
Tumor in the left atrium with hepatic metastasis
Tumor in the appendix without metastasis
Tumor in the lung without metastasis
Tumor in the descending colon with hepatic metastasis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While a tumor in the pancreas could be a serotonin-producing neuroendocrine tumor that causes carcinoid syndrome, systemic symptoms are normally not seen in the absence of hepatic metastasis. Metabolites produced by a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor would be degraded by the liver (first pass effect), making this diagnosis unlikely in this patient. Other more common neuroendocrine pancreatic tumors such as somatostatinoma, glucagonoma, and insulinoma do not secrete serotonin and, therefore, would not manifest with carcinoid syndrome.

B) CORRECT:

The small intestine (especially the terminal ileum) is the most common location of a neuroendocrine tumor. A gastrointestinal neuroendocrine tumor with hepatic metastasis (or beyond) causes systemic symptoms of carcinoid syndrome, as large quantities of vasoactive metabolites (serotonin, histamine, VIP) circulate throughout the body without being degraded in the liver. In the heart, serotonin can cause endocardial fibrosis, resulting in carcinoid heart disease. In patients with carcinoid heart disease, the right side of the heart is typically affected as the lungs enzymatically inactivate the metabolites; therefore, the left side of the heart is usually spared. Increased serotonin metabolism explains this patient's elevated 5-HIAA levels and has resulted in pellagra (niacin deficiency), which classically manifests with the triad of diarrhea, dementia, and dermatitis.

In patients with a metastasized neuroendocrine tumor with a patent foramen ovale, high amounts of tumor products pass directly from the right atrium to the left atrium, bypassing the pulmonary circulation, and causing damage to the left side of the heart.
Image Description:

Left: Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) located in the gastrointestinal tract are usually asymptomatic because most of the hormones they produce are metabolized by the first-pass effect in the liver (although local tumor growth may be symptomatic). Disseminated NETs (most commonly with liver metastases) and primary extraintestinal NETs bypass or impair this process and are more likely to be symptomatic.

Right: symptoms of the carcinoid syndrome

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial myxoma is the most common primary cardiac tumor in adults. A myxoma growing in the mitral area could cause a murmur, which is seen in this patient. However, the murmur caused by an atrial myxoma is usually diastolic and heard over the apex of the heart (similar to mitral stenosis) rather than systolic and heard at the left lower border. Additionally, atrial myxomas are not neuroendocrine tumors and therefore would not cause elevated 5-HIAA levels and carcinoid syndrome. Finally, cardiac myxomas are usually benign and do not metastasize.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the appendix is a common site of neuroendocrine tumors, systemic symptoms are not normally seen in the absence of hepatic metastasis. Metabolites produced by a neuroendocrine tumor in the appendix are degraded by the liver via the first pass effect.

E) INCORRECT:

While a tumor in the lung could be a serotonin-producing carcinoid tumor that causes carcinoid syndrome, systemic symptoms are rarely seen in lung neuroendocrine tumors in the absence of metastasis. Neuroendocrine tumors of the lung secrete smaller amounts of vasoactive metabolites than neuroendocrine tumors of the gastrointestinal tract. Additionally, a neuroendocrine tumor of the lung would affect the left heart rather than the right heart. Because the lung inactivates neuroendocrine metabolites, carcinoid heart disease is exceedingly rare in patients with lung neuroendocrine tumors.

F) INCORRECT:

A tumor in the descending colon with hepatic metastasis would most likely be an adenocarcinoma, the most common type of colorectal cancer. This patient's symptoms, however, are consistent with carcinoid syndrome caused by a neuroendocrine tumor. Although neuroendocrine tumors can occur in the gastrointestinal tract, they would typically be found in the terminal ileum or the appendix.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation (e.g., cutaneous vasomotor flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, and cardiac involvement) is highly suggestive of carcinoid syndrome. 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) is a metabolite of serotonin, the primary molecule produced by neuroendocrine neoplasms. Carcinoid heart disease is typically caused by valvular and endocardial fibrosis that affects the right heart, leading to right-sided valvular disease (e.g., tricuspid regurgitation).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with a complaint of worsening diarrhea during the past several months. She also notes increasingly frequent episodes of facial redness and warmth.
On physical examination, a faint systolic murmur that increases with inspiration can be auscultated along the left sternal border. Laboratory testing reveals an elevated 24-hour urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid level. CT of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis reveals a large intestinal tumor with suspected metastatic disease in the liver and lungs.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate to relieve this patient’s symptoms and help control her tumor?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that usually secrete excessive amounts of serotonin. In patients with disseminated disease, high levels of serotonin cause the level of its metabolite, 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid, to rise in the serum and urine, leading to carcinoid syndrome. Symptoms of carcinoid syndrome include diarrhea, flushing of the face and neck, wheezing, and edema. Excess serotonin can also lead to fibrosis of the tricuspid and pulmonary valves.

Localized carcinoid tumors are often surgically resected and are not associated with systemic symptoms produced by serotonin, but disseminated disease must be treated systemically. Treatment includes somatostatin analogues, such as octreotide, which can relieve the symptoms of carcinoid syndrome and control tumor growth.

Key learning point: The most appropriate treatment to relieve symptoms of diarrhea and flushing associated with carcinoid syndrome while controlling tumor growth is a somatostatin analogue, such as octreotide.

B) INCORRECT:

Crizotinib is indicated for the treatment of non-small-cell lung cancer and certain other tumors but not neuroendocrine tumors.

C) INCORRECT:

Interferon alfa may be used in patients who do not respond to octreotide, but it is not considered a first-line therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Diphenoxylate-atropine can control the diarrhea associated with carcinoid syndrome but does not control tumor growth.

E) INCORRECT:

Loperamide can control the diarrhea associated with carcinoid syndrome but does not control tumor growth.

questions.text:
A 59-year-old man presents with 6 months of intermittent flushing, watery diarrhea, and occasional wheezing. He is otherwise healthy and denies any new medications or dietary changes. Examination shows mild facial erythema but is otherwise normal. Laboratory results are otherwise unremarkable (see lab result and report).


Heart rate
82/min


Blood pressure
125/80 mm Hg


Temperature
37.2°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



Urine




 5-HIAA
15 mg/24 hours
2 - 8 mg/24 hours



CT scan of the abdomen: 2-cm mass in the distal ileum with calcifications in the adjacent mesentery
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Carcinoid tumors, a type of neuroendocrine tumor, commonly originate from enterochromaffin cells in the distal ileum. They secrete serotonin and other vasoactive substances, leading to symptoms such as intermittent flushing, watery diarrhea, and bronchospasm. Elevated urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) levels indicate increased serotonin production. Imaging showing a mass in the distal ileum with mesenteric calcifications suggests a desmoplastic reaction, typical of carcinoid tumors. This combination of clinical symptoms, laboratory findings, and imaging is consistent with excessive serotonin secretion from a carcinoid tumor.

Key learning point: Elevated urinary 5-HIAA and a small bowel mass with calcifications are indicative of a carcinoid tumor, a type of neuroendocrine tumor that secretes serotonin.

B) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GISTs) typically present with mass effect symptoms such as bleeding or obstruction, not systemic hormone-related symptoms. The elevated urinary 5-HIAA and symptoms of flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing suggest hormone secretion, which is not characteristic of GISTs. The imaging findings also do not align with typical GIST presentation.

C) INCORRECT:

Small bowel adenocarcinomas usually present with obstruction or nonspecific abdominal pain, not systemic symptoms like flushing and diarrhea. The elevated 5-HIAA level indicates serotonin metabolism, associated with neuroendocrine tumors, not adenocarcinomas. The mesenteric calcifications on imaging suggest a fibrotic reaction, not typical of adenocarcinoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Gastrinomas secrete gastrin, causing acid hypersecretion and symptoms like refractory peptic ulcer disease and abdominal pain. The elevated urinary 5-HIAA and symptoms of flushing, wheezing, and diarrhea are not typical of gastrinomas. Additionally, gastrinomas are usually located in the pancreas or duodenum, not the distal ileum.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman presents with 6 months of episodic facial flushing. The episodes start abruptly and last several minutes before resolving spontaneously. She also reports occasional watery stools and mild shortness of breath. She denies recent travel or new medications. Examination reveals a distinct mid-diastolic murmur along the left sternal edge.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test to confirm the suspected underlying cause of her presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gastrin stimulation testing assesses gastrin-secreting tumors, such as in Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, characterized by peptic ulcers and acid hypersecretion. The patient's symptoms, including flushing and a cardiac murmur, suggest carcinoid syndrome rather than a gastrinoma.

B) CORRECT:

The patient presents with symptoms indicative of carcinoid syndrome, including episodic facial flushing, watery diarrhea, and a mid-diastolic murmur suggestive of right-sided heart involvement. Carcinoid syndrome results from serotonin-secreting neuroendocrine tumors. Serotonin is metabolized to 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is excreted in urine. A 24-hour urine 5-HIAA measurement quantifies this metabolite, confirming serotonin overproduction. Patients should avoid certain foods that may interfere with the test to ensure accurate results.

Key learning point: Carcinoid syndrome is characterized by flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, and heart murmurs, and is diagnosed by elevated levels of 5-HIAA in the urine.
Image Description:

Left: Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) located in the gastrointestinal tract are usually asymptomatic because most of the hormones they produce are metabolized by the first-pass effect in the liver (although local tumor growth may be symptomatic). Disseminated NETs (most commonly with liver metastases) and primary extraintestinal NETs bypass or impair this process and are more likely to be symptomatic.

Right: symptoms of the carcinoid syndrome

C) INCORRECT:

The plasma metanephrine assay screens for pheochromocytomas, which present with hypertension, headaches, palpitations, and diaphoresis. The patient's symptoms, including facial flushing, diarrhea, and a cardiac murmur, align more with carcinoid syndrome than pheochromocytoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Serum calcitonin measurement evaluates medullary thyroid carcinoma, which can present with flushing and diarrhea. However, the mid-diastolic murmur suggests right-sided heart involvement typical of carcinoid syndrome, not medullary thyroid carcinoma.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 10-month history of nonbloody diarrhea and recurrent episodes of flushing and wheezing. She does not take any medications. On examination, there is a hyperpigmented rash around the base of her neck. Cardiac examination reveals a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. Echocardiography shows right-sided endocardial and valvular fibrosis with moderate tricuspid regurgitation; there are no septal defects or left-sided valvular defects. Urinalysis reveals increased 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration. Which one of the following is the most likely explanation for her symptoms?

choices.text: Tumor in the lung without metastasis.
Tumor in the pancreas without metastasis.
Tumor in the left atrium with hepatic metastasis.
Tumor in the terminal ileum with hepatic metastasis.
Tumor in the descending colon with hepatic metastasis.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While a tumor in the lung could be a serotonin-producing carcinoid tumor that causes carcinoid syndrome, systemic symptoms are rarely seen in lung neuroendocrine tumors in the absence of metastasis. Neuroendocrine tumors of the lung secrete smaller amounts of vasoactive metabolites than neuroendocrine tumors of the gastrointestinal tract. Additionally, a neuroendocrine tumor of the lung would affect the left heart rather than the right heart. Because the lung inactivates neuroendocrine metabolites, carcinoid heart disease is exceedingly rare in patients with lung neuroendocrine tumors.

B) INCORRECT:

While a tumor in the pancreas could be a serotonin-producing neuroendocrine tumor that causes carcinoid syndrome, systemic symptoms are normally not seen in the absence of hepatic metastasis. Metabolites produced by a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor would be degraded by the liver (first pass effect), making this diagnosis unlikely in this patient. Other more common neuroendocrine pancreatic tumors such as somatostatinoma, glucagonoma, and insulinoma do not secrete serotonin and, therefore, would not manifest with carcinoid syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Atrial myxoma is the most common primary cardiac tumor in adults. A myxoma growing in the mitral area could cause a murmur, which is seen in this patient. However, the murmur caused by an atrial myxoma is usually diastolic and heard over the apex of the heart (similar to mitral stenosis) rather than systolic and heard at the left lower border. Additionally, atrial myxomas are not neuroendocrine tumors and therefore would not cause elevated 5-HIAA levels and carcinoid syndrome. Finally, cardiac myxomas are usually benign and do not metastasize.

D) CORRECT:

The small intestine (especially the terminal ileum) is the most common location of a neuroendocrine tumor. A gastrointestinal neuroendocrine tumor with hepatic metastasis (or beyond) causes systemic symptoms of carcinoid syndrome, as large quantities of vasoactive metabolites (serotonin, histamine, VIP) circulate throughout the body without being degraded in the liver. In the heart, serotonin can cause endocardial fibrosis, resulting in carcinoid heart disease. In patients with carcinoid heart disease, the right side of the heart is typically affected as the lungs enzymatically inactivate the metabolites; therefore, the left side of the heart is usually spared. Increased serotonin metabolism explains this patient's elevated 5-HIAA levels and has resulted in pellagra (niacin deficiency), which classically manifests with the triad of diarrhea, dementia, and dermatitis.

In patients with a metastasized neuroendocrine tumor with a patent foramen ovale, high amounts of tumor products pass directly from the right atrium to the left atrium, bypassing the pulmonary circulation, and causing damage to the left side of the heart.

Key learning point: Carcinoid syndrome with right-sided heart involvement occurs when a neuroendocrine tumor, usually in the terminal ileum, metastasizes to the liver, allowing serotonin and other vasoactive substances to bypass hepatic degradation and enter systemic circulation.
Image Description:

Left: Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) located in the gastrointestinal tract are usually asymptomatic because most of the hormones they produce are metabolized by the first-pass effect in the liver (although local tumor growth may be symptomatic). Disseminated NETs (most commonly with liver metastases) and primary extraintestinal NETs bypass or impair this process and are more likely to be symptomatic.

Right: symptoms of the carcinoid syndrome

E) INCORRECT:

A tumor in the descending colon with hepatic metastasis would most likely be an adenocarcinoma, the most common type of colorectal cancer. This patient's symptoms, however, are consistent with carcinoid syndrome caused by a neuroendocrine tumor. Although neuroendocrine tumors can occur in the gastrointestinal tract, they would typically be found in the terminal ileum or the appendix.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation (e.g., cutaneous vasomotor flushing, diarrhea, wheezing, and cardiac involvement) is highly suggestive of carcinoid syndrome. 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) is a metabolite of serotonin, the primary molecule produced by neuroendocrine neoplasms. Carcinoid heart disease is typically caused by valvular and endocardial fibrosis that affects the right heart, leading to right-sided valvular disease (e.g., tricuspid regurgitation).

questions.text: You are seeing a 45-year-old woman in your clinic who reports fatigue, abdominal cramps, watery diarrhea, and a 4-kg weight loss over the past 4 months. She has recently avoided alcohol and spicy foods because they worsen her diarrhea and trigger episodes of heart palpitations and flushing of her face and neck. She takes lisinopril for hypertension. Her temperature is 36.5°C, pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 149/90 mm Hg. On examination, her abdomen is soft with mild tenderness to palpation, without guarding or rebound. Laboratory studies reveal an increased urine 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid concentration. Further evaluation will most likely show which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Achlorhydria is seen in patients with VIPoma, a condition that manifests with watery diarrhea, tea-colored stools, and hypokalemia. Although approximately 20% of patients experience flushing symptoms, they typically do not have abdominal pain. Moreover, VIPoma is associated with increased serum concentrations of vasoactive intestinal peptide, not increased urine 5-HIAA concentration.

B) CORRECT:

Pulmonic valve stenosis is a manifestation of carcinoid heart disease, a condition that eventually affects > 50% of patients with carcinoid syndrome. Carcinoid heart disease typically develops as a result of chronic exposure of the heart to serotonin from liver metastases. Serotonin enters the inferior vena cava and reaches the right side of the heart, where it induces valvular and myocardial fibrosis. This can lead to pulmonary valve stenosis, tricuspid insufficiency, and right-sided heart failure.

Key learning point: Carcinoid syndrome can cause right-sided heart lesions, most commonly pulmonic valve stenosis and tricuspid regurgitation, due to serotonin-induced valvular fibrosis.
Image Description:

Left: Neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) located in the gastrointestinal tract are usually asymptomatic because most of the hormones they produce are metabolized by the first-pass effect in the liver (although local tumor growth may be symptomatic). Disseminated NETs (most commonly with liver metastases) and primary extraintestinal NETs bypass or impair this process and are more likely to be symptomatic.

Right: symptoms of the carcinoid syndrome

C) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma can manifest as an adrenal medullary mass and cause episodic hypertension, palpitations, tachycardia, and sweating. However, this malignancy does not typically cause abdominal cramps or diarrhea. Moreover, laboratory changes associated with pheochromocytoma include increased urine concentrations of catecholamines and metanephrines, not increased urine 5-HIAA.

D) INCORRECT:

Purple-red colored urine is observed in patients with acute intermittent porphyria (AIP), which also manifests with abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and, during acute attacks, hypertension and tachycardia. In addition, alcohol can precipitate attacks of AIP. However, affected patients typically experience neurological symptoms (e.g., sensory and motor neuropathy, neuropsychiatric symptoms). Moreover, laboratory changes associated with AIP include increased serum and urine concentrations of porphobilinogen, delta-aminolevulinic acid, and porphyrins, not increased urine 5-HIAA concentration.

E) INCORRECT:

Multiple peptic ulcers can result from excessive gastrin secretion due to a gastrinoma, which also manifests with severe abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. However, this woman has episodic palpitations and facial flushing triggered by food and alcohol, which are not features of a gastrinoma. Moreover, gastrinoma is associated with increased serum concentrations of gastrin and chromogranin A, not increased urine 5-HIAA concentration.
questions.hint: This woman has carcinoid syndrome, which manifests with abdominal cramps, diarrhea, and episodic cutaneous flushing and palpitations triggered by food ingestion. The diagnosis is confirmed by laboratory testing that shows an increased urine concentration of 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), which is a product of serotonin metabolism.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 4-month history of intermittent episodes during which her face and neck become pink. The episodes last 5–10 minutes and occur 3–4 times daily. She reports these episodes are sometimes triggered by red wine but can occur spontaneously. She has chronic watery diarrhea without blood or mucus, with 6–8 loose stools daily. She also experiences intermittent shortness of breath and wheezing, particularly during the flushing episodes. Physical examination shows mild peripheral edema and a 3/6 systolic murmur heard best at the left sternal border that increases with inspiration. Echocardiography shows tricuspid regurgitation with thickened valve leaflets and mild right ventricular dysfunction. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Order serum tryptase levels and consult hematology
Obtain CT angiography of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While hyperthyroidism can cause flushing and diarrhea, it does not typically cause the specific episodic pink flushing pattern, wheezing, or right-sided valvular fibrosis seen in this patient. The chronic nature and cardiac findings suggest carcinoid syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Mastocytosis can manifest with flushing, diarrhea, and abdominal pain, and serum tryptase levels are elevated in systemic mastocytosis. However, this patient's specific pattern of episodic flushing, right-sided valvular disease with tricuspid regurgitation, and chronic secretory diarrhea are more consistent with carcinoid syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

While pulmonary embolism can cause right heart strain, this patient's chronic symptoms, episodic flushing, and diarrhea are not consistent with acute thromboembolic disease. The tricuspid valve thickening suggests chronic fibrotic changes rather than acute right heart strain.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's presentation is not consistent with allergic reaction or histamine-mediated flushing. Allergic reactions do not cause chronic secretory diarrhea or progressive right-sided valvular disease with tricuspid regurgitation.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- The combination of episodic flushing, secretory diarrhea, wheezing, and right-sided valvular disease with tricuspid regurgitation strongly suggests carcinoid syndrome. 24-hour urine collection for 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) is the first-line diagnostic test, and oncology consultation is appropriate for further management, including tumor localization and treatment planning.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with a six-month history of episodic facial flushing, watery diarrhea, and intermittent wheezing. She was recently diagnosed with asthma but has had no relief with albuterol. A chest CT performed for a persistent cough showed a 2-cm well-circumscribed endobronchial mass. A subsequent 24-hour urine collection showed an elevated 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid level. The patient is scheduled for a surgical consultation but is seeking treatment for her debilitating symptoms in the interim. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy to manage this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Loperamide is an opioid-receptor agonist used to treat diarrhea by slowing intestinal motility. Although it might offer partial relief for this patient's diarrhea, it is a symptomatic treatment for only one aspect of her condition. It does not address the underlying hormonal overproduction from the neuroendocrine tumor and has no effect on the flushing or wheezing.

B) CORRECT:

Carcinoid syndrome is caused by a neuroendocrine tumor secreting vasoactive substances such as serotonin. The elevated urine 5-HIAA, a serotonin metabolite, confirms this diagnosis. Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, is the first-line therapy for symptomatic management. It binds to somatostatin receptors on the tumor cells, inhibiting the synthesis and release of serotonin and other hormones. This directly addresses the underlying cause of the flushing, diarrhea, and bronchoconstriction, providing comprehensive symptom relief while the patient awaits definitive surgical treatment. It is also used to prevent carcinoid crisis during surgery.

C) INCORRECT:

Cisplatin and etoposide are cytotoxic chemotherapy agents. This regimen is often used for high-grade neuroendocrine carcinomas, such as small cell lung cancer. However, this patient's well-circumscribed mass is more consistent with a well-differentiated (typical) neuroendocrine tumor. Furthermore, the immediate goal is symptomatic control, not definitive oncologic therapy, which would be considered for metastatic or aggressive disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Cyproheptadine is a serotonin and histamine antagonist. Because serotonin is a key mediator of carcinoid syndrome, this drug may seem plausible. However, it is considered an option for refractory diarrhea. It is less effective than other established therapies, which prevent the release of multiple vasoactive substances from the tumor, rather than just blocking the effect of one.

E) INCORRECT:

Sunitinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, a form of targeted cancer therapy. It is approved for advanced, progressive, well-differentiated pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. It is not the first-line agent for initial symptom management of carcinoid syndrome, especially from a bronchial primary.
questions.hint: This patient's constellation of flushing, diarrhea, and wheezing, along with an endobronchial mass and elevated 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA), suggests carcinoid syndrome.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician because of palpitations, shortness of breath, diarrhea, and abdominal cramps for 2 months. Physical examination shows cutaneous flushing of the face. Auscultation of the chest shows bilateral wheezing. A 24-hour urine collection shows increased 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) concentration. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen shows an intestinal tumor with extensive metastasis to the liver. A diagnosis of an inoperable disease is made, and the patient is started on treatment with octreotide. Six weeks later, the patient's symptoms have improved except for his abdominal pain and frequent loose stools. The physician suggests enrolling the patient in a trial to test additional treatment with a new drug that has been shown to improve symptoms in other patients with the same condition. The expected beneficial effect of this new drug is most likely caused by inhibition of which of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dopamine beta-hydroxylase is an enzyme of catecholamine synthesis that converts dopamine into noradrenaline. Although elevated catecholamines can lead to palpitations, shortness of breath, and facial flushing, this patient's symptoms are caused by excess serotonin. This enzyme is not involved in serotonin synthesis, so inhibition of dopamine beta-hydroxylase is unlikely to improve this patient's symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) is a hormone that can cause abdominal pain, diarrhea, and flushing. However, carcinoid syndrome is not associated with elevated VIP levels, so VIP inhibition is unlikely to improve this patient's symptoms. Abnormally increased VIP is seen in patients with VIPomas, which can also be treated with octreotide.

C) INCORRECT:

Plasma kallikrein is part of the kinin cascade, which releases bradykinin from high-molecular-weight kininogen. Bradykinin excess can cause dyspnea, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Although excess production of kallikrein can cause carcinoid syndromes, kallikrein inhibitors (e.g., ecallantide) are not approved for treating these syndromes. These agents are used to treat bradykinin excess in hereditary angioedema.

D) INCORRECT:

Histidine decarboxylase converts histidine to histamine, which can cause anaphylactic symptoms such as dyspnea, wheezing, cutaneous flushing, abdominal cramps, and diarrhea. Carcinoid syndromes can be caused by excess production of this vasoactive substance, so reducing histamine levels may be beneficial, but there are no histidine decarboxylase inhibitors currently approved for clinical use.

E) CORRECT:

Tryptophan hydroxylase is an enzyme that converts tryptophan into serotonin. Carcinoid syndromes are caused by the excess production of various vasoactive substances; serotonin is the most prominent and is the primary cause of gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., diarrhea). Telotristat, an inhibitor of tryptophan hydroxylase, is used as adjunctive therapy for patients with carcinoid syndromes whose diarrhea is not controlled with somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide).
Image Description:

Important cofactors and constituents appear in blue boxes.
questions.hint: Palpitations, dyspnea with wheezing, flushing, and diarrhea in a patient with a metastatic intestinal tumor and increased urinary 5-HIAA suggest carcinoid syndrome.
